prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What does Jami mean?
completion: The choice of the name Jami was inspired by the Swahili word jamii which means community as a noun and together as an adverb.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is the green dot next to my account?
completion: A red dot means that your account is disconnected from the network, it turns green when its connected###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Why should I backup my account?
completion: Jami is distributed and you're account is only stored on your device. If you loose your password, or your datas you can't recover it###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Can I make a conference call?
completion: In a call, you can click on "Add participants" to add a contact to a call###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Does Jami have group chats?
completion: In the settings, you can enabled support for groups (experimental)###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is a Jami account?
completion: A Jami account is an asymmetric encryption key. Your account is identifie by a Jami ID, which is a fingerprint of your public key.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What information do I need to provide to create a Jami account?
completion: When you create a new Jami account, you don’t have to provide any private information like an email, address, or phone number.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Why don't I have to use a password?
completion: With Jami, your account is stored in a folder on your device. The password is only used to encrypt your account in order to protect you from someone who has physical access to your device.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Why don't I have to register a username?
completion: The most permanent, secure identifier is your Jami ID, but since these are difficult to use for some people, you also have the option of registering a username.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I back up my account?
completion: In the account settings, a button is available to backup your account.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What happens when I delete my account?
completion: Your account is only stored on your own devices. If you delete your account from each device, the account is gone and you cannot get it back.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Can I use my account on multiple device?
completion: Yes, you can link your account from the settings, or you can import your back-up on another device.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is Jami?
completion:
Jami is an innovative communication system. It doesn't work like other solutions since its designed to protect user's freedom.

The Jami network is [distributed](https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/uploads/9b725e440c2705a2a3c4d0a3df092066/Network-topo.png), hence, you may be invited to perform some actions that are considered bad practices on centralized or decentralized systems, but that are totally acceptable with Jami.

- Jami is fundamentally different from other communication tools
- Jami protects the privacy of its users
- A Jami account is stored on the device, it must be saved###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

It misses a feature!
completion:
Not all features are implemented in all clients yet.
Check list at: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/features/All-features-by-client
Contributions to this document are greatly appreciated!

If you can't wait to have this feature, you can try another client.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Jami just crashed / have a bug. What can I do?
completion:
- A bug report. This is a very useful way to contribute to Jami. Please have a look at https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/tutorials/Bug-report-guide and https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/tutorials/Reporting-bugs.
- If you can, try another client###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

There's a orange / red exclamation side by my avatar. What does it mean?
completion: It's because your account is not connected to the DHT. Verify your internet connection or try to relaunch the application. If you use the push notifications, try to disable this option (and re-enable it).###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Where are the configuration files located
completion:
Jami saves its configuration (account, certificates, history) at
different locations depending the platform.

-   'GNU/Linux': global configuration is under
    '~/.config/jami/dring.yml' and Accounts files are under
    '~/.local/share/jami/'. Finally some cache can be stored in '~/.cache/jami'
-   'OSX': The full configuration is under '~/Library/Application
    Support/Jami' if installed via https://jami.net. Via the appstore it's '~/Library/Containers/com.savoirfairelinux.ring.macos/Data/Library/Application Support/jami'
-   'Android': The full configuration is under '/data/data/cx.ring'
    (may require root privileges)
-   'Windows': global configuration is under
    '%AppData%/Local/jami/dring.yml' and Account files are under
    '%AppData%/Local/jami/'. Finally, some caches are in '%USERPROFILE%/.cache/jami'

Note: audio and video messages are recorded in the local-data in the folder: sent_data###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is a Jami account?
completion:
Jami is not like a lot of communication software. It's not based on any central server and your account is only stored on your device. When you want to use Jami with your account, you don't have to use a classical login/password authentification.

When you create a new Jami account, you don't have to provide private informations like a mail or a phone number. But this is the informations you can provide (all optionals):

1. An avatar
2. A display name, it's the name client will display on your contact entry with the avatar. It can contains special character.
3. A username, this is a unique identifier and can be the direct translation of your JamiID. This identifier is stored on a server (ns.jami.net by default). Cf https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol for more details on how you can use your own name server.
4. A password. This password is used to protect the account archive in your device.

So, after this step, the client will generate an archive (protected by the password you gave). This archive will contains your account's keys. And a JamiID is now created (a 40 chars length string. Technically, this ID is the fingerprint of your public key. And that's it, you have a Jami account.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

No password?
completion:
With Jami, you are not forced to have a password on your account.
Don't worry, it's a decentralized system, consequences are not the same than on other systems.

With a centralized system, you use your password to authenticate on a public server. Someone who knows your password can usurp your identity.

'With Jami, your account is stored in a [folder]((#basics-5)) on your device'. The password is only used to protect you from someone who have a physical access to your device by encrypting the account's archive (and don't let anyone access your private key)

If your device is encrypted, you may not want/need to use a password.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

No username?
completion:
For a while, Jami had no username management system. Instead, we had to use [Infohashs](guidelines/Identifiers). They are quite difficult to use for most people (ie : 3d1112ab2bb089370c0744a44bbbb0786418d40b). To mitigate the issue, we created a system that associate your [Infohashs](guidelines/Identifiers) to a username of your choice that will be much more easier to remember. We recommand you to create a username: Jami will be friendlier.

The technology we used to associate a username to a [Infohashs](guidelines/Identifiers), Ethereum blockchain, is also [distributed](https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/uploads/9b725e440c2705a2a3c4d0a3df092066/Network-topo.png), but it doesn't allow to modify or delete the association between a username and a InfoHash.

You can still create an account without a username if you wish. Please note that if you choose this option, it is still possible to register a username later.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I back-up my account?
completion:
There is two ways to back-up your account:

1. Link another device to your account, so your account will be in two devices. You can find this option in the account's settings page.
2. Copy the account's archive on a USB flashdrive or any another place. This file can be found in the paths given in the previous question. In the linux client, you can export this archive from the client in the account's settings page.

The content of the export.gz is explained here: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/2.1.-Manage-Accounts#how-it-works-from-scratch but it's basically a gunzipped Json (AES encrypted if a password is set)###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I retrieve my username without my keys?
completion:
It depends. If you used ns.jami.net, you can't. There is no way to prove it's your username without your key (and there is no way to change your current username).
If it's another name server, it depends if it's possible to change the username linked. See this page for more details: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I forgot my password, what can I do?
completion:
Nothing. Because we don't have access to your datas, we can't have an option like 'I forget my password'. You are the only one in charge of your datas, so take care.
If you are scared to forget a password, please use a password manager.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is the PIN when I want to link my account to another device
completion: When you choose to 'link your device with another account', you have to enter the password of your account on your first device and a PIN. This PIN is generated by the first device, when you click on 'Link this account to another device' (Generally in Settings, Accounts, Choose your account, Link this account to another device), the account will be sent on the DHT during 5 minutes and a PIN is generated at this moment. This is the PIN you need to enter on the other device.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How to delete my account?
completion:
'Accounts without Infohash'

A Jami account only exists on linked devices with this account. So, you only have to delete this account in app on all these devices and your account will not exists anymore. Or to uninstall Jami.
If you delete the account's archive, your account will no longer exists. If you uninstall Jami, your data will be deleted too. And nobody will be able to retrieve your account. Never ever.

- GNU/Linux

In the settings page, go to *Accounts*, choose your account and click on the 'Delete' button in the GUI.

- Android

In the hamburger menu, choose 'Manage accounts', choose the account to delete and click on the trash icon.

'Note for accounts with a username'

The technology that handle usernames is also distributed. So, it depends the nameservice you choose to make the translation between a nickname and your Jami ID. By default, a username is registered on ns.jami.net where you can't modify the Jami ID associated to this username. So, if you delete or if you lost your account you will not be able to retrieve this username, ever. Nobody will be able to recreate an account with the same username.

NOTE: If your account has a username, this username will not be deleted. For example, if you use the username pseudo on the name server ns.jami.net, when you will delete your Jami account and you create a new account, you will not be able to retrieve this username, because ns.jami.net can't prove it's your username.

If you do not want to lose your account, please back-up files related to this one.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What happens when I bind my account to a new device?
completion: When you start the binding procedure, the folder containing your account information is simply put on the Jami network for a few minutes. It is protected by a password Jami gives you.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

My contact is not seeing my avatar
completion: Due to technical limitations of distributed technologies, avatars are only transfered to your contacts when a call (audio or video) is established.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How to configure echo cancellation?
completion:
Go to settings, media, and set change your audio manager.
We recommend using Pulse audio.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Video is laggy
completion:
Use a lower definition. Go to settings, media, and change resolution.
You can also try auto mode by clicking the HQ button during a call.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I can't see myself
completion:
End call and check that you have selected the right video device.
Go to settings, media, and change device.

Check that you can effectively see yourself in the right panel of settings, media.
You can double check that your device is working by installing the cheese application.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Others can't ear me
completion: End call and try changing audio driver or audio input device.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I have no sound
completion: End call and try changing audio driver or audio output device.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How much bandwidth do I need?
completion:
For audio calls, Jami uses about 100 Kbps. For a video call, you need about 2 Mbit/s for medium quality (if the link doesn't allow it, the bitrate will be automatically reduced).

If you are hosting a video conference, you will need approximately 2 Mbps more per participant. So, for a conference with 10 participants, each participants will need 2Mbps up & down, except the host will need 20Mbps up and down.

Auto-adaptation is done between 200Kbit/s / max:6Mbit/s###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What data passes through my machine when I participate in the Jami network?
completion:
'All these data are encrypted'.
There is:

- ICE descriptors of other Jami users. ICE is a protocol that help establishing communication between two computers
- certain text messages
- as indicated above, accounts currently being linked to a new device

Audio/video streams and some text messages pass through the VOIP protocol.
Text messages can be sent either via VOIP or DHT (the distributed network) depending on whether a VOIP communication channel is already open or not.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Why am I able to communicate with myself?
completion: Many users use Jami to transfer data from one machine to another.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Should I enable push notifications?
completion: Push notifications allow Jami to operate in a way more adapted to the context of mobility (energy consumption, data...). However, for the moment, notifications go through Google's servers, via the Firebase service. Only one identifier is transferred and it is unusable for anyone who does not have access to your account.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is DHT proxy?
completion: The DHT proxy is a server that registers on the DHT for you and relays your information to you. Thus, it is the server that will be active on the DHT and will participate in the network, and no longer the target device. Multiple devices can register on the same DHT proxy.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How the username registration service work?
completion: For default parameters the usernames are registered on an Ethereum blockchain. By default, it's ns.jami.net that is used, but if you are a developper, you can create your own system. Hence, nothing forces you to implement it with a blockchain. You can check results at http://ns.jami.net/name/test, where 'test' is a username for which we are looking for a matching [Infohashs](guidelines/Identifiers). Once registered, this server doesn't provide a way to remove the mapping. More informations there: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I change the timeout for a call?
completion: In the dring.yml file, you can change your ringingTimeout (in seconds)###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How to back up and reimport conversations and accounts
completion:
Note: This is only for client based on LRC (desktop ones)

First you will need to export all your accounts (For GNU/Linux: Settings, Account, Export account). Then you will need to copy the database (in ~/.local/share/jami for example).

Then on the new device, when you will open Jami for the first time, you have to re-import your accounts via the archive previously saved. This will re-import your settings and contacts (with empty conversations). Then close the client and replace the database with the one previously saved. That's all!###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How secure are you?
completion:
' We use TLS/SRTP to secure connection and communications over the network.'

We implement SRTP over SIP using recommendations written in following
RFCs:

- [http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3711](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3711)
- [http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4568](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4568)

Typically 2 kind of sockets are negotiated. One for the control socket, the other for the media sockets

Typical control session will use the following cipher suite:
(TLS1.3)-(ECDHE-SECP384R1)-(RSA-PSS-RSAE-SHA384)-(AES-256-GCM) (TLS_ECDHE_RSA_AES_256_GCM_SHA384)

DTLS (fallback) supported: 'SECURE192:-KX-ALL:+ANON-ECDH:+ANON-DH:+SECURE192:-VERS-TLS-ALL:+VERS-DTLS-ALL:-RSA:%SERVER_PRECEDENCE:%SAFE_RENEGOTIATION'
TLS: 'SECURE192:-KX-ALL:+ANON-ECDH:+ANON-DH:+SECURE192:-RSA:-GROUP-FFDHE4096:-GROUP-FFDHE6144:-GROUP-FFDHE8192:+GROUP-X25519:%SERVER_PRECEDENCE:%SAFE_RENEGOTIATION'

Supported crypto suite for the media session are:

- AES_CM_128_HMAC_SHA1_80 / SRTP_AES128_CM_HMAC_SHA1_80
- AES_CM_128_HMAC_SHA1_32 / SRTP_AES128_CM_HMAC_SHA1_32###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

When do public IPs get exposed?
completion:
We can describe 3 main connectivity scenarios. A classic configuration (1.), behind a VPN (2.), via Tor (3.). As Jami is a p2p app, I think you understand that (2.) or (3.) is a bit mandatory to avoid IP leaking.

Moreover, even if it's my answer, you can choose to not trust my answer and check the code, or use wireshark or other tools. Generally, I (and the other devs I think) are using the first scenario (sometimes the second one), and we surely can't test all the network we want, so if you discover a bug, please open a issue.

Anyway, in these 3 scenarios, there is 3 main actions:

+ Send a message (this will use the DHT)
+ Send a file (TCP ICE connection as described here: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/2.5.%20File%20transfer)
+ Do a call (TCP + UDP ICE connection as described here: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/2.4.%20Let's%20do%20a%20call)
###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What ports does Jami use?
completion:
Jami works as a server and gets new ports for each connections (randomly binded). These are the ranges that can be used for each component:

+ dht: UDP [4000, 8888]
+ audio: UDP [16384-32766]
+ video: UDP [49152-65534]
+ SIP Control: UDP/TCP randomly binded

Note: if UDP is blocked, a dhtproxy can be used to use TCP instead. Note that medias will not work cause it only supports UDP.

So for ufw, we recommend to run:
sudo ufw default allow outgoing

For now, you can't specify a specific range to configure ports used by Jami. The inbound traffic can be controlled without issue, Jami should work and can use a TURN server if needed.

If you run your own proxy or nameserver:

+ dhtproxy, nameserver: TCP [80-100], 443

If you run your own TURN server:

+ TURN/STUN: TCP+UDP 3478, 5349
###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I configure the codecs even more?

Answer to this issue:

Where is the changelog?
completion: There is a changelog dedicated page in the wiki of the project.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Fully self hosting Jami

Being serverless is an amazing thing I found out about Jami. I want to fully host/build my own android and ios apps and I do not want to depend on any of jami services or if possible, other external services as well.

I see in the docs about installing own turn server. This left me thinking that what are other things in addition to a turn server that I would need to launch fully self owned apps.

So is it just that I build the app and put information of my turn server in the app and users who download my app will be able to chat, make audio/video calls and do everything you list or claim this app does?
completion:
This article https://jami.net/why-is-jami-truly-distributed/ list:

push notifications
the OpenDHT proxy
bootstrap
name server
TURN.

For Turn, you said that you did it.
For the name server it's here: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol
For the bootstrap it's here (and DHT proxy): https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/opendht/wiki/Running-a-node-with-dhtnode
For push notifications: https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/opendht/wiki/Push-notifications-support
However, push notifications are a specific case if you want to support it. Indeed, it's Google (or Apple) who owns the server that will send notifications. Authentification is done via a certificate which signs the app. So, if you want your push server, you will have to regenerate yourself the binaries for iOS and Android.
But Jami can also work without any Turn server, but yeah if you replace turn.jami.net by yours, all features should work.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

If I do not use turn server at all, what features I will be missing?
completion: TURN is only used to contournate the NAT. So, generally if you have 2 IPv4 behind a NAT (and without UPnP), without TURN the socket will not be created. So call/file transfer can fail behind NATs.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How we can self host Jami?

Hello Jami Team,

We are working on a Video Conferencing application for which we have to choose Jami to build that solution.

We have our own iOS, Android & Web application in which we want to use Jami as an embedded system, When a user is on our app he/she can start a video call using our application instead of the Jami mobile application.

We are looking for a solution with Jami that can embed in our mobile application and our backend engine is written in PHP (Laravel) that can manage the session between participants.
Is there any way I can achieve this using Jami and JAMS?
completion:
Hi.
Jami provides a lot of APIs (dbus/jni/rest) and the code is available for all, so yeah it should be achievable. Also, https://review.jami.net/jami-web can be interesting.
For a more detailled answer for

When a user is on our app he/she can start a video call using our application instead of the Jami mobile application.

What does it really mean? What protocols will be used, what part is in charge of negotiation, medias, etc. What part of the application should be handled by Jami and how it interacts?
So the answer is yes probably. For the how, it depends###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Code coverage?
I could not find any test coverage scripts and metrics. It could be great, if jami-client-android's code coverage was observable
completion:
Jami is divided in two parts, the daemon which contains a lot of things and is common on every platform and then clients such as Android which has a small logic part and a big UI part.
For now, for jami-client-android there is no unit test/coverage but we hope to get a bench for integration tests one day, but it's a complete project that we can't prioritize right now.
However coverage for the daemon part is a thing and updated every night here: https://docs.jami.net/coverage/
And may be separated for the desktop client too. As the swarm is not merged, the shown coverage is not the best right now, as a part of the code is sleeping until swarm, but yeah, every links should be on https://docs.jami.net###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Does registering user name on nameserver decrease decentralization nature of Jami ?
completion:
Distributed != Decentralization
No. It's optional, you can host it yourself if you follow https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol (I use a single json on my website)
However, as ns.jami.net is default, it will be used by many users, and if jami.net is down you will not have access to it. However, ids will still be there and Jami will continue to work, except for lookups on ns.jami.net (but other nameservers will be able to work).###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

TURN vs STUN?
In account settings i can enable STUN server (and i have to enter host name). But there is already enabled (by default) TURN server. How it works? If i enable both settings? Do I need to specify a port number (like stun.host.com:3478)?
completion: It will add all candidates to the SDP sent to the peer. So if both settings are enabled, you will send all ip and the peer will try to pass through all links and choose the best###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

how to improve audio quality?
completion: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/tutorials/Frequently-Asked-Questions#how-can-i-configure-the-codecs-even-more###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Can you explain me why a TURN is necessary to run this app?
completion: A TURN server is necessary to run this app because it allows for communication between devices that are behind NAT firewalls.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I'm wondering why TURN is enabled by default as this is a peer-to-peer application?
completion: The TURN server is used to relay data between peers when a direct connection cannot be established. This can happen for a variety of reasons, such as NAT or firewall restrictions. By default, the TURN server is enabled to provide the best possible connection quality for all users.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How do notes to self work?
How do I send messages or files to myself from one device to another? I have already linked my account.
completion: You can add yourself to your own contact to start a conversation with yourself. Or a group that you call 'Notes to self'###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How does Jami work without opening any ports from router
Hello, I know Jami is peer to peer but how does it work without opening any ports etc.? How does it communicate with a device in a network? How does it know which device to communicate in the same network(using the same external ip address)?
completion: Jami uses the ICE protocol to communicate with peers. So, each peers will send a list of address to try to reach, and during the negotiation, the best link will be choosen.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is the required knowledge to develop a new plugin?
completion: The required knowledge to develop a new plugin is C++. All of current plugins are written in that language.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

What is required to build a plugin?
completion: Each plugin is different from another. You can have a plugin that depends on some libraries and others that don’t. For instance, GreenScreen depends on onnx, opencv and ffmpeg while AutoAnswer does not require any additional dependencies. Apart from that, all plugins will share: clang for Android, gcc for MacOS and Linux and CMake (Visual Studio 16 2019) in Windows.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Connection Details (See how your connected to the Jami network)
It is not clear in the Jami app how to tell if your connected to the Jami network using openDHT, TURN servers, or STUN servers. It would be great to see for each contact potentially how your connected to them to indicate to the user if it is a direct P2P connection or if it uses TURN or STUN servers instead.
Would help for troubleshooting any connection issues.
completion: In General settings, Troubleshoot, get logs. The first phase will do a monitor and show all sockets through all peers.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Can I use Jami in a local network (LAN) without internet access?
completion:
Yes!  Thanks to Jami's architecture, Jami users on a local/private
network can communicate among themselves using Jami, without requiring
any outside connectivity such as the internet.
To do so, from Jami's Account settings open Advanced account
settings.  There, enable the Enable local peer discovery
setting.  Additionally, you may want to manually set the bootstrap
node's address (default: bootstrap.jami.net) to the IP address of
another device on your network that also runs Jami and/or an OpenDHT
node.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

How can I configure the audio processor?
completion:
An audio processor allows Jami to clean up and process your microphone's audio.
It can remove echo, reduce noise, and equalize your microphone's volume.
Additionally, it can detect when you're speaking and send this information to participants in your call.
The audio processor settings can be set in your dring.yml file.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I do not receive notifications on android until I manually launch jami app
I have a OnePlus 6T and using the last version of the Jami available from F-droid. After closing all the apps no more notifications received until I open again the Jami App. I have do reviewed and no battery restrictions applied.
It's normal?
completion:
Hi and thank you for the feedback,
Because there is no push notifications, the android app needs to work without battery restrictions. One way is to enable the 'Run in background option' in the system settings of the application.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

I also want to know which security risk is implies by opening UPnP. It seem to be risky for the user (As I see lot of recommendations say not use UPnP).
completion: Because Jami is a peer to peer application, UPnP is enabled to be able to use the most possible techniques to workaround heavily NATed restrictions. For those not familiar with UPnP, in summary what it does is that it allows networked devices, such as personal computers, printers, Internet gateways, Wi-Fi access points and mobile devices to seamlessly discover each other’s presence on the network and establish functional network services for data sharing, communications, and entertainment. The challenge with UPnP is that, for example, routers, printers, and other devices can be remotely commandeered by a new attack that exploits a security flaw in the Universal Plug and Play network protocol. And UPnP has a very long history of weak security.###

completion: CPU usage could indeed be an issue in a video-conference, as there is no hardware acceleration for mixing multiple videos inputs. We recommend to use the most powerful device to host a video-conference.###

completion: The main problem is that GNU/Linux got several desktop environments without a real common way to get the system theme. And this can generally break the identity of a software. So, for now, the developpers choose to only add a toggle to switch between white and dark theme.###

Incorrect contact status

Some service which is supposed to update the UI doesn't seem to update the UI. I tried looking in to the Android code, I am not able to easily find where the Green Circle is redrawn
completion: The green dot on contacts is not really for the presence, but it means that a device is announced over the DHT. So, even if detected as announced, it may not answer (internet down). If it uses a proxy, this presence will stay twelve hours, else ten minutes.###

Answer to this issue:

High mobile data consumption
I experienced high and excessive mobile data consumption on a Samsung and a Huawei device.
Jami was used on both devices for about 3 hours. Less than 15 text messages were exchanged between both devices. On both devices the 'share location for 1 hour' function was enabled twice.
completion: Hi, on mobile, the best thing to have a limited data consumption is to disable syncing with the rest of the DHT network and enable the DHT proxy with push notifications support.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Add new contact to chat with, hanging on Downloading conversation from peer
I have just installed GNU Jami on my phone and computer, and also on my mothers' phone. We both set up accounts, and she added me as a contact. So far so good.I saw the invitation appear in my client, so I clicked it to accept it, and now on both her and my installation, it just says
, and hasn't changed since the invitation was accepted (about 3 hours ago from the time of me writing this).
completion: To initalize a swarm conversation, one side must download the first part of the conversation created by the other. So, it will be downloaded whenever both sides are online (or with the next detected presence change).###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Please enable online status to be set (with corresponding colors):  Online/absent/busy
completion: For now it's indeed not possible, but may be in the future. However, the presence is on the DHT and it will be always detected (to encrypt messages), so the offline status will not exist.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Being serverless is an amazing thing I found out about Jami. I want to fully host/build my own android and ios apps and I do not want to depend on any of jami services or if possible, other external services as well.
I see in the docs about installing own turn server. This left me thinking that what are other things in addition to a turn server that I would need to launch fully self owned apps.
completion:
This article https://jami.net/why-is-jami-truly-distributed/ list:
push notifications
the OpenDHT proxy
bootstrap
name server
TURN.
For Turn, you said that you did it.
For the name server it's here: https://git.jami.net/savoirfairelinux/ring-project/wikis/technical/Name-Server-Protocol
For the bootstrap it's here (and DHT proxy): https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/opendht/wiki/Running-a-node-with-dhtnode
For push notifications: https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/opendht/wiki/Push-notifications-support
However, push notifications are a specific case if you want to support it. Indeed, it's Google (or Apple) who owns the server that will send notifications. Authentification is done via a certificate which signs the app. So, if you want your push server, you will have to regenerate yourself the binaries for iOS and Android.
But Jami can also work without any Turn server, but yeah if you replace turn.jami.net by yours, all features should work. Also a lot of documentation is on https://docs.jami.net.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Provide changelogs for all updates
Especially for the client updates. Many people who are not so technique affine are often just annoyed - in my perception - of constantly doing updates. A friend recently asked me what the update of his Jami Windows client actually changed/improved. Unfortunately I couldn't tell him either. This would probably change if people understood - maybe before the updates - why they should do the update.
completion: There is a changelog dedicated page in the wiki of the project.###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

It would be really great to be able to discover other Jami users on the local network.
completion: This feature is available in the account settings (enable local peer discovery)###

prompt:
Answer to this issue:

Add a way to recover usernames.
My suggestion is that the usernames become free after a while (eg after 6 months of inactivity). That way active users would have the opportunity to recover or use their favorite usernames.
completion: It depends the nameserver, but the default one doesn't register any personal informations, so there can't be somewhat like I forgot my password. However if you host your own nameserver, if it's following the REST API (it's in the doc), you can implement whatever you want###
